page.title: 03LANDSCAPE 2
page.content: Apart from the{Alluvium}(marshes where the Wantsum Channel once ran) there are two kinds of high ground in the Stourmouth area. Firstly, the ground at{Stourmouth}rises only a few feet above the marsh, it is composed of brickearth and gravel over chalk. Although the rise in level is very subtle it is made obvious by the change in vegetation. There are large trees and all flora is adapted to dry conditions. Across the marsh to the north is part of the{Isle of Thanet. Here the Upper Chalk rises steeply (over 20m in less than 500m) to become Downland. The soil is a rendsina and very fertile, forming part what has become know as Thanet's "cabbage prairie". Fields on the marsh{flood}in the winter making Stourmouth appear an island.
